hint: It’s received more praise than any architectural work in Seattle in the past decade.
caption: The diamond-shaped glass panels on the outside of the Seattle Public Library are made differently depending on where they are. The glass is clear on parts of the building that don’t see much sun, but on the sunny parts the glass includes a layer of thin metal that reduces heat. The sun sees the glass as opaque, but from the inside, the glass looks transparent.

hint: It was the tallest building in Seattle when it was built (a century ago).
caption: Smith Tower’s crowning pyramid, with its Gothic arched dormers (the windows), takes after the Metropolitan Life Tower in Manhattan. The developer, Lyman Cornelius Smith, and his architects were from Syracuse, and they fashioned Smith Tower after the New York “mounted tower” form: a substantial base with a slender tower. What’s inside the pyramid today? Probably the most perfect penthouse apartment in Seattle.
designer: Edwin H. Gaggin and T. Walker Gaggin

hint: Well, it’s a sculpture of a walrus ...
caption: Yes, it’s the one with the walrus heads, part of the building’s Arctic theme; it housed the Arctic Club, where a men’s club of Alaskan gold rush veterans could smoke, dance and shoot pool. The molded walrus tusks were replaced with plastic tusks in the 1940s; the owners feared the tusks would fall off and impale people on the sidewalk.
designer: George W. Lawton and A. Warren Gould

hint: This art-deco building was originally named the Northern Life Tower.
caption: No building in Seattle roars '20s like the art-deco Seattle Tower. Insurance tycoon D.B. Morgan wanted to build something "finer than anything on the Pacific Coast,” and his building, originally called the Northern Life Tower, dramatically changed the Seattle skyline. It’s meant to evoke the surrounding mountains: The step-like setbacks are like rock formations leading to the building’s peak, and the brick, which becomes gradually lighter near the top, resembles snow. The three metal rods at the top are supposed to look like evergreens.
designer: Abraham H. Albertson, Joseph W. Wilson and Paul D. Richardson

hint: The six people and a dog in Fremont aren’t the only ones waiting for this building’s namesake.
caption: The lion head at the corner entrance of the Interurban Building (so named for the nearby Tacoma Interurban railway terminus) is one example of the Richardsonian Romanesque influence on John Parkinson’s design. The building was one of the first constructed after the Great Seattle Fire of 1889, and it received praise for the pressed brick, the rounded corners, the uniform clay color.

hint: Remember, it's a close-up of the building (not the reflection)!
caption: The metallic color called "shimmering Purple Haze" finishes the exterior of the EMP Museum, which houses memorabilia of Jimi Hendrix and Nirvana. The blob-like shape of the building is still considered hideous by many, but its inspiration is on point: Frank Gehry used broken pieces of electric guitars to create the initial design.

The cream-colored, glazed terra cotta horse head identifies the original function of Union Stables, built at a time when automobiles were already replacing horse-drawn carriages. But the building housed other things beside horses over the years, including cars, furniture — and a stash of booze, stacked floor to ceiling, during Prohibition. It has recently been converted into office space.

hint: The design scheme, "seven bottles of light in a stone box," also represents aspects of Catholic worship.
credit: Ken McCown, Courtney Blethen Riffkin / The Seattle Times
reveal: It's the Chapel of St. Ignatius.
caption: Steven Holl's acclaimed design of Chapel of St. Ignatius was all about "seven bottles of light in a stone box." Stone curvatures, each with windows on the end, reach out in seven directions from the building's base. The windows collect light through colored lenses, casting a mix of color and angles into the interior.

hint: You might recognize this as the Washington Mutual Building, but now its name is more generic.
credit: Tony Jolly, Dean Rutz / The Seattle Times, 2012
caption: Though you might recognize this building as the Washington Mutual Building, that now-defunct financial company moved across the street to the WaMu Center in 2006. But 1201 Third Avenue is still Seattle’s second-tallest highrise (for now), and its post-modern design remains popular. It mixes modern sleekness and traditional details, and the design winks at surrounding buildings: The pyramid top, capped by a lantern, recalls the tops of buildings like Smith Tower and Harborview Medical Center.
designer: Bill Pedersen (Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates) and The McKinley Architects

caption: The “Beaver Building,” so nicknamed because its stem-like base looks like the handiwork of a giant beaver, was designed by modernist Minoru Yamasaki. Yamasaki was sometimes criticized for adding decorative elements to his buildings (like the non-functional, or “fake,” arches to the IBM building), but the porcelain ceramic tiles on Rainier Tower's base have a purpose: They make the building easier to clean.

hint: The fortress on Beacon Hill more commonly known as "the PacMed Building."
credit: Flickr user Wonderlane, Steve Ringman / The Seattle Times
caption: The art-deco building was originally the U.S. Marine Hospital, for veterans and merchant seamen​, and later the home for Amazon.com. Art-deco motifs, like graphic brick decoration and precise line work, reflect the building's origins: a time of new technology, jazz and Cubist art. The basket-weave patterns that dot the building's brick and terra cotta are mirrored in the newer etched glass.

hint: This church is one of the remaining architectural quirks of Capitol Hill.
credit: Courtney Blethen Riffkin / The Seattle Times
reveal: It’s St. Nicholas Russian Orthodox Cathedral.
caption: The onion dome was a staple of Russian Orthodox churches, starting in the 17th century. They are popularly believed to symbolize burning candles. The domes are gold; the domes of the St. Spiridon Orthodox Cathedral in South Lake Union are blue.
